item.title: Some South Korean Workers Return to Georgia Factory After U.S. Reissues Visas
item.description: The State Department has reissued visas for many workers detained in a September raid, lawyers said, as the Trump administration tries to undo damage from the operation.

item.title: In the Faroe Islands’ Soccer Team, the Players Also Have Day Jobs
item.description: The Faroe Islands, rugged green specks in the North Atlantic, are an underdog. Most of the guys on the team have day jobs.

item.title: Juan Ponce Enrile, a Political Power in the Philippines, Dies at 101
item.description: A protégé of Ferdinand Marcos, he helped administer martial law for eight years before turning on his patron in the “People Power” uprising of 1986.

item.title: Ukraine’s Dilemma as Pokrovsk Teeters: Save Lives or Keep Holding On
item.description: Military analysts and some Ukrainian commanders worry that Kyiv may be repeating the mistake of staying in an embattled city longer than it should, aiming to inflict far more casualties than it suffers.

item.title: China’s ‘Wolf Warrior’ Diplomacy Returns With Threat Against Japan’s Leader
item.description: A Chinese diplomat’s call to cut off the prime minister’s “filthy head” signaled a revival of a combative style Beijing had tried to dial back.

item.title: I Watched This Haven From War Turn Into a Besieged Wasteland
item.description: The Ukrainian city of Pokrovsk is on the verge of becoming another shattered trophy for the Russian Army.

item.title: Former Syrian Security Official Indicted in Austria
item.description: Prosecutors say a Syrian security official accused of torture hid in plain sight in Europe for years, protected by Israeli and Austrian intelligence agents.

item.title: How Pakistan’s Spending Blitz Helped Win Over Trump and Flip U.S. Policy
item.description: As Pakistan has hired lobbyists with close ties to President Trump, it has also received favorable tariff treatment and unique access in Washington.

item.title: Fake Bomb Threats Baffle the Police Across Asia
item.description: The threatening emails and faxes bear the signature of a man who says he is being impersonated. The police in five nations have failed to stem them.

item.title: He Helped Cities Anticipate Damage From Storms
item.description: Austin Becker developed an early warning system to protect critical infrastructure from storms. His project’s funding was eliminated in April.

item.title: Man Accused of Running Southeast Asia Scam Compound Is Extradited to China
item.description: China and the United States say She Zhijiang, a Chinese-born businessman, ran a major scam compound in Myanmar. He was arrested in Bangkok in 2022.

item.title: Trump Is Said to Propose Opening California Coast to Oil Drilling
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a chief critic of the president and an opponent of oil exploration in the Pacific, called the proposal “dead on arrival.”

item.title: Syria’s Leaders Pledge to Join Fight Against Islamic State
item.description: Large parts of Syria were once overrun by the terrorist group Islamic State. The country’s new government has just committed to a global effort to fight the group.

item.title: How France Remembers the November 2015 Terrorist Attacks in Paris
item.description: A decade ago, Islamic State militants killed 130 people in an assault that shocked France. Some survivors are still struggling, but for many of their compatriots, memories of the attacks are growing more distant.

item.title: South Asia on Edge
item.description: There are no known links between two bomb attacks in India and Pakistan, but they come as tensions between the countries are already high.

item.title: Rubio Shrugs Off Allies’ Concerns Over U.S. Drug Strikes
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said no one raised the Caribbean military operation in closed-door meetings at a G7 summit. But ministers from France and the European Union publicly called them unlawful.

item.title: Greenhouse Gas Emissions Head for a Record in 2025, Global Carbon Project Reports
item.description: But there are signs that greenhouse gas pollution in China might be slowing, according to a new analysis.

item.title: Iraq’s Prime Minister Leads in Elections but May Struggle to Form a Government
item.description: Mohammed al-Sudani pitches himself as someone who can keep Iranian influence in check, but his vote share may not be big enough to ensure a clear political victory.

item.title: Labour Party’s Internal Fight Goes Public, as Starmer’s Trouble Grows
item.description: An attempt by Keir Starmer’s allies to undercut a rival has forced into the open a party debate over whether to replace the prime minister.

item.title: How to Capture the Northern Lights With Just Your Smartphone
item.description: Modern cellphone cameras make it easy to capture the famously fickle Aurora Borealis.

item.title: Israel Reopens Gaza Aid Route It Had Closed for Months
item.description: The cease-fire with Hamas has blunted the hunger faced by Gazans during the war. But aid agencies say Israeli restrictions are still hobbling their work.

item.title: Algeria Pardons Writer Boualem Sansal at Germany’s Request
item.description: Boualem Sansal, an Algerian-French writer, was arrested on accusations of undermining national security during a visit to his homeland a year ago and sentenced to five years in prison.

item.title: Deadly Blasts in India and Pakistan Set Region on Edge
item.description: The rare explosions in the country’s capitals have not been directly linked, but there are fears the governments will blame each other after their previous military conflict alarmed the world.

item.title: Gustavo Petro, the Rebel Turned President Willing to Take on Trump
item.description: From his guerrilla roots, Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, has long embraced a confrontational style. Now, he has incurred President Trump’s wrath and is facing political fallout at home.

item.title: Blue Diamond Sells for $25.6 Million at Auction in Switzerland
item.description: A 9.51-carat blue stone that once belonged to the heiress Bunny Mellon sold for $7 million less than at its last auction, a sign of profound shifts in the diamond industry.

item.title: As Belgium Races to Save U.S.A.I.D. Contraception, Some Supplies Are Reported Ruined
item.description: The Belgian government is in talks with the Trump administration to save birth control stranded in a warehouse, but another shipment has been incorrectly stored.

item.title: Pakistan’s Army Chief Is Granted Sweeping Authority Over All Military Branches
item.description: A constitutional amendment in the nuclear-armed country extends the chief’s power over all the military and brings Pakistan’s highest court under tighter political control.

item.title: How the Heavy-Metal Fall of a Dictator Shapes Trump’s Venezuela Plans
item.description: Seizing Panama’s leader was relatively easy. But the similarities between Panama and Venezuela are dangerously misleading, some analysts warn.

item.title: The ‘Lost Sisters’ of the Pleiades Fill the Entire Night Sky
item.description: Astronomers identified more than 3,000 stars associated with the cluster, and there might be even more.

item.title: Many Displaced Sudanese Feared Dead After Shipwreck Near Libya
item.description: Forty-two migrants were presumed dead after a rubber boat capsized off the Libyan coast this month. Many of the presumed victims were fleeing a raging conflict in Sudan.

item.title: Senator Criticizes Rubio for Paying $7.5 Million to Equatorial Guinea to Take Deportees
item.description: Senator Jeanne Shaheen, Democrat of New Hampshire, said the African country has a long history of corruption. The amount paid is far more than recent annual assistance given to it.

item.title: There’s a New Forecast for Peak Oil Demand. It’s Increasingly Cloudy.
item.description: The International Energy Agency once projected that oil and gas demand could level off by 2030. Now it’s backing off, sort of.

item.title: Turkish Military Plane Crashes in Georgia, Killing 20 Troops
item.description: The Turkish defense minister said that 20 Air Force servicemen died when their military cargo plane crashed after taking off from Azerbaijan on Tuesday.

item.title: India’s Prime Minister Vows Justice After New Delhi Car Explosion Kills 8
item.description: Those responsible for the explosion “will not be spared,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said. The blast killed at least eight people near a subway station at evening rush hour.

item.title: Japan’s Prime Minister Faces Backlash Over 3 A.M. Staff Meeting
item.description: Sanae Takaichi drew criticism for requiring staff to work in the wee hours in a country scarred by “death from overwork.”

item.title: Blood and Tears as Spain’s Troubled Bullfighting Star Hangs Up His Cape
item.description: José Antonio Morante Camacho says he has fought his last bull. Fans appreciated his artistry but also his honesty about his struggles with mental illness.

item.title: A Look Into the Early Days of Migrant Detentions at Guantánamo
item.description: Government employees distributed Bibles and prepared materials “commonly used in Hinduism, Sikhism and Rastafarianism,” according to emails.

item.title: How a New Bridge Partly Collapsed in China’s Southwest
item.description: A section of the tall bridge in mountainous Sichuan Province fell, apparently after a landslide. No casualties were reported.

item.title: Newsom in the Spotlight at the Climate Conference That Trump Decided to Skip
item.description: The California governor painted the president as a threat to American competitiveness by letting China dominate the renewable energy industry.

item.title: Xi’s Military Purges Show Unease About China’s Nuclear Forces
item.description: The shake-up in China’s armed forces comes as both Beijing and Washington are pushing through major changes in their country’s militaries, in different ways.

item.title: What It Takes to Move a Factory From China to Vietnam
item.description: Tariffs have forced Chinese companies to move their operations to Vietnam. Alexandra Stevenson, our Shanghai bureau chief, visits a factory in Ho Chi Minh City to see how one of the biggest challenges isn’t relocating machinery and tools, but overcoming language barriers.

item.title: Women in Power, and on the Right
item.description: Two G7 countries now have female leaders, and they have something in common.

item.title: Pakistan ‘in a State of War’ After Explosion Kills 12 in Capital
item.description: An attack on a courthouse in Islamabad was the first major assault to hit Islamabad in more than a decade.

item.title: ‘It Feels Like I’m in a Nightmare’: Inside the First Deportation Flight to Iran
item.description: For decades, Iranians fleeing persecution have found protection in the United States. But this fall, the Trump administration deported a planeload of people to Iran after making a deal with Tehran.

item.title: Key Netanyahu Minister Steps Down From Israel’s Government
item.description: Ron Dermer, a longtime ally of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and an influential figure in the Israeli government throughout the war in Gaza, resigned as minister of strategic affairs.

item.title: Israel Arrests 4 After Jewish Extremist Attack in West Bank
item.description: Dozens of masked Israelis attacked an industrial zone, torching vehicles and wounding Palestinians, according to Palestinian officials.

item.title: Trump Threatened to Sue the BBC for $1 Billion. What Are His Chances?
item.description: Legal experts say President Trump’s litigation track record offers both hope and warning to the British public broadcaster, which he has threatened with a $1 billion suit.

item.title: Iraqis Are Voting for a New Parliament. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Iraq is caught in a power struggle between Washington and Tehran, with the Trump administration insisting that the next government disarm powerful Iran-backed militias.

item.title: These Sheep Have a Statement to Make
item.description: How fashion connected a designer, a farmer, Grindr and a herd of male-oriented rams.

item.title: Roman-Era Treasures Stolen From Syria’s National Museum
item.description: The Damascus museum theft set off an official investigation in what may be one of Syria’s largest losses of antiquities in recent years.

item.title: Turkey Seeks Jail Sentence of Over 2,000 Years for Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu
item.description: Prosecutors accused Ekrem Imamoglu, the mayor of Istanbul, of leading a criminal organization. The opposition called the case politically motivated.

item.title: As Iraqis Vote for a Parliament, U.S. Presses to Rid Country of Iran’s Influence
item.description: After a U.S. occupation, years of sectarian violence and a jihadist insurgency, Iraq has become an improbable haven of calm in the Middle East.

item.title: Ban a Pro-Palestinian Group? The U.K. Government Thought Few Would Care.
item.description: Official advice provided to the government before its ban on Palestine Action underestimated the significant public protests that followed, records show.

item.title: The Mysterious ‘Louvre Detective’ Was a 15-Year-Old Passer-by
item.description: The photo of a dapper man in a fedora sparked many questions: Was the person real? A Sherlock Holmes-inspired detective on the case? Or just being very French?

item.title: Trump Pardons Runner Who Took Prohibited Shortcut on Grand Teton
item.description: Michelino Sunseri broke a speed record for running up and down the Wyoming peak, but was convicted of using a restricted path.

item.title: How China Reached Into New York to Stop a Tiny Film Festival
item.description: A showcase for independent Chinese films was scrapped after the Chinese authorities pressured directors, moderators and even a volunteer to pull out.
